text.title: Direct and Indirect Object Pronouns Part 3

paragraphs.content: Direct and indirect object pronouns do not only have the unstressed (or weak) forms that we saw in Units 7, 10, and 13: they also have **stressed** (or strong) forms:
* As usual, the pronoun **Lei** (third person singular feminine) and the pronoun **Loro** (third person plural) are used for the **formal form**.

sections.title: Use of Stressed Pronouns for Emphasis or Contrast

paragraphs.content: The stressed forms of direct and indirect object pronouns are used to give emphasis to the pronoun or to stress a **contrast**; unlike **unstressed forms**, they normally come **after the verb**, except when used with the verbs **piacere**, **sembrare**, **servire**, **bastare**, **parere**, and **mancare** (see Unit 11). Stressed forms always refer to people, not objects:

rows: I can see her, but I can’t see him.
I’m waiting for Francesco, not you.
I’m only inviting you, Mr Paoli.
I think it’s fair/It seems fair to me.
I’ll phone you, but not them.
Billy scrive **a noi** e non **ai suoi genitori**.
Billy writes to us and not his parents.
Devi rendere i soldi **a me**, non **a mio fratello**.
You’ve got to give me the money, not my brother.

paragraphs.content: Note the difference between the two sentences **Non mi piace il caffè** and **A me non piace il caffè**. The first simply states that I don’t like coffee, while the second puts the **emphasis** on the pronoun **me**, implying that there are people who do like coffee but I am not one of them. The same applies to the sentences **Mi sembra giusto** and **A me sembra giusto**: the second sentence stresses the fact that there are other people who don’t think it’s fair.

sections.title: Stressed Pronouns Refer to People, Not Objects

paragraphs.content: As the above examples suggest, stressed direct and indirect object pronouns *cannot be used to refer to objects*. When referring to objects, the noun has to be repeated (as is also generally the case in English):

rows: ‘Prendi **la frutta** e **il dolce**?’ ‘Prendo **la frutta**, ma non **il dolce**.’ [Not ‘Prendo **lei**, ma non **lui**.]
‘Are you having the fruit and the sweet?’ ‘I’m having the fruit, but not the sweet.’
‘Porti **la chitarra** e **i CD**?’ ‘Porto **i CD** ma non **la chitarra**.’ [Not ‘Porto **loro** ma non **lei**.]
‘Are you bringing the guitar and the CDs?’ ‘I’ll bring the CDs, but not the guitar.’ [or, at a pinch, ‘I’ll bring them, but not it.]

paragraphs.content: The stressed forms of the object pronouns are used after all prepositions (see Unit 8), not just **a**. This is true even when no emphasis is required:

rows: Which of them doesn’t want to come?
You can sleep at my place tonight.

paragraphs.content: * When **su**, **sopra**, **dopo**, **contro** are used with a personal pronoun, the pronoun is preceded by the preposition **di** (see Unit 8, paragraphs 9, 20).
The **stressed forms** are also always used when the verb has two pronoun **direct** or **indirect objects**, even where no **emphasis** is required:

rows: **Ho visto te e lui** in città. [not Ti e lo ho visto in città.]
I saw you and him in town.
**Invito voi e loro**. [not Vi e li invito.]
**Scrive a te e a me**. [not Ti e mi scrive.]
He writes to you and me.
**Regaliamo fiori a loro e a lei**. [not Gli e le regaliamo fiori.]
We’re giving flowers to them and her.

paragraphs.content: **Stressed forms** are always used after **anche/pure** (also, too), **neanche/nemmeno/neppure** (not even, neither), **come** (as, like), **quanto** (as much as), **eccetto (che)**, **meno (che)**, **tranne (che)**, **salvo (che)** (except, but):

rows: You should do as I do/do it like me.
Maria works as much as you (do).
You have to ask *us* as well.
They’re all coming except him/Everyone but him’s coming.
Faccio questo per tutti meno che* per lei.
I’m doing / I’ll do this for everyone except/but her.
Anna telefona a tutti salvo che* a loro.
Sandro esce con tutti salvo che* con noi.
Sandro goes out with everybody except/but us.

paragraphs.content: * The forms **eccetto che**, **meno che**, **tranne che**, **salvo che** are used when there is a preposition before the pronoun.

sections.title: Non-Agreement with Stressed Pronouns in Compound Tenses

paragraphs.content: Note that when the stressed forms of the direct object pronouns are used in a sentence with the verb in a compound tense (see Unit 13, paragraph 1), the past participle does not agree with the pronoun:

rows: Ho visto lei, ma non ho visto lui.
I saw *her*, but I didn’t see him.
Lucia ha invitato loro, ma non lui.
Lucia has invited *them*, but not him.

exercises.title: Exercise 1: Replace with Italian Pronouns
exercises.instruction: Replace the English words with the correct **Italian stressed pronouns**.
examples: Prima accompagno (**her**) a scuola, poi (**you [sing.]**) in palestra.: Prima accompagno **a lei** a scuola, poi **a te** in palestra.
Dovete invitare anche (**them**).: Dovete invitare anche **a loro**.

items.question: Prima accompagno (**her**) a scuola, poi (**you [sing.]**) in palestra.
Dovete invitare anche (**them**).
Non è venuto nessuno, nemmeno (**her**).
Hanno invitato (**us**) e non (**you [pl.]**)?!
All’esame hanno promosso tutti tranne (**me**).
Credo a tutti meno che a (**him**).
Carla vuole bene a (**me**) quanto a (**you [sing.]**).
A (**you [polite]**) credo, Professore.
Voglio presentare i miei amici anche a (**you [pl.]**).
A (**her**), come a (**them**), non sembra giusto.

exercises.title: Exercise 2: Translate with Emphasis
examples: Nobody plays the drums **like me**.: Nessuno suona la batteria **come me**.
All the students did the homework except **him**.: Tutti gli studenti hanno fatto i compiti eccetto **di lui**.

items.question: Nessuno suona la batteria come me.
Tutti gli studenti hanno fatto il compito meno lui.
items.answer: Every student but him did the homework.

items.question: Sergio chiama te, non me.
Accompagno anche te.
answer: I’ll go with you as well.

items.question: Capisco quanto te.
answer: I understand as much as you.
I understand as much as you do.

items.question: Mauro dice la verità a tutti, tranne che a me.
answer: Mauro tells everyone the truth but me.
Mauro tells everyone the truth except me.

items.question: Dovete telefonare anche a me.
answer: You should call me as well.
You must call me as well.
You have to call me as well.

items.question: Claudia impresta i dischi a noi, non a voi.
items.answer: Claudia’s lending us the records, not you.

items.question: Do il mio indirizzo a tutti salvo che a lei.
answer: I'm giving my address to everyone but her.
I’ll give my address to everyone but her.

items.question: Regalo un libro a lei e un disco a lui.
items.answer: I’m giving her a book and him a record.

exercises.title: Exercise 3: Replace with Italian Pronouns
exercises.instruction: Replace the English words with the correct Italian stressed pronouns.
examples: Chi di (**you [pl.]**) non può venire alla festa?: Chi **di voi** non può venire alla festa?
All’esame orale sono passato subito dopo di (**him**).: All’esame orale sono passato subito **dopo di lui**.

items.question: Chi di (**you [pl.]**) non può venire alla festa?
All’esame orale sono passato subito dopo di (**him**).
Sopra di (**them**) abita una signora molto gentile.
Abbiamo deciso fra (**us**).
Esci con (**her**) anche stasera?

exercises.title: Exercise 4: Translate into Italian
exercises.instruction: Translate into Italian, using the **stressed form** of the pronouns.
examples: Everyone’s against **me**!.: Tutti sono contro **di me**!
Are you [sing.] coming with **me**?: Vieni **con me**?

items.question: Everyone’s against **me**!
Are you [sing.] coming with **me**?
I’ve bought a present for **you [sing.]**.
items.answer: Ho comprato un regalo per te.

items.question: You [sing.] can’t count on **him**.
items.answer: Non puoi contare su di lui.

items.question: Can I sleep at **your [pl.]** place tonight?
